entry.title: Rob on Category Theory
entry.summary:
Hi all!

This Friday, February 16 Rob will give us an introduction to Category Theory. Hope to see you all there!

entry.title: Schedule and Meeting Time
entry.summary:
Hi all!

We revised the meeting time for this semester to: 1:30-2:30 pm, Fridays. The next meeting (2/9) is cancelled.

entry.title: Schedule and First Meeting
entry.summary:
Hi all!

The meeting time for this semester is Fridays, 11:15-12:15 pm. The next meeting will be held on February 2. Jeff Heinz will give an introduction to Automata Theory, string/tree transductions, and Myhill-Nerode.

Hope to see you all there!
entry.content:
Hi all!

Hope to see you all there!

entry.title: Hossep Continuing on Reduplication
entry.summary: This week, Hossep will continue his presentation from last week on reduplication. details and papers can be found from last week’s announcement. See you on Friday!
entry.content: This week, Hossep will continue his presentation from last week on reduplication. details and papers can be found from last week’s announcement. See you on Friday!

entry.title: Sam van Gool Tutorial
entry.summary: This week there is no MathLing meeting due to the holiday, but as a special treat, please enjoy the slides from Sam van Gool’s Fontiers talk last Friday on the Google drive! Those looking for an extended version may visit his website.
entry.content: This week there is no MathLing meeting due to the holiday, but as a special treat, please enjoy the slides from Sam van Gool’s Fontiers talk last Friday on the Google drive! Those looking for an extended version may visit his website.

entry.title: Hossep on “Computing Reduplication: Typology and Learning”
entry.summary: This Friday, Hossep will present “Computing Reduplication: Typology and Learning”, based on his recent manuscript Reduplication with Finite-State Technology”, which is uploaded to the Google Drive. See you Friday!
entry.content: This Friday, Hossep will present “Computing Reduplication: Typology and Learning”, based on his recent manuscript Reduplication with Finite-State Technology”, which is uploaded to the Google Drive. See you Friday!

entry.title: Alena on “Formal Restrictions on Multiple Tiers”
entry.summary:
Hi all!

This Friday, Alena will present her recent manuscript “Formal Restrictions on Multiple Tiers”. The abstract is below. See you all Friday!

Abstract: The class of tier-based strictly local (TSL) languages has shown itself as a good fit for natural language patterns. Although there are some cases when one …
entry.content:
Hi all!

This Friday, Alena will present her recent manuscript “Formal Restrictions on Multiple Tiers”. The abstract is below. See you all Friday!

Abstract: The class of tier-based strictly local (TSL) languages has shown itself as a good fit for natural language patterns. Although there are some cases when one TSL grammar is not enough, there have never been proposed any limitations on tier alphabets of several cooperating TSL grammars. Here, we use harmonic systems with multiple feature spreadings as the litmus test for the possible configurations of tier alphabets. While theoretically possible relations among them are containment, disjunction and intersection, the latter one is unattested and we show why the absence of such configuration might simplify the system in whole.
